ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: How to challenge scholarly texts about museums and question Yale's legacies.
Gained knowledge about how museums function, (i.e. museum theory, science and technology studies, feminist studies, Indigenous studies) and current issues animating museum discourses

This course really helped to reshape How I interacted with and interpretes the museum. It increased my awareness of how small details and decisions worked together to influence the image the museum creates.

I learned about the origins and intellectual histories of what museums are, how museums were created, why they were created, and what purposes they serve in our lives today. I also learned about the current critical discourse about the museum, its problematic history, and what current movements are being led by Indigenous scholars and activists to dismantle the current institution of the museum.
Museum label analysis/writing, writing a review of museum exhibit, reflecting on the museum visitor experience

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: very manageable reading/workload, but we almost never got any feedback on assignments. everything has been pretty great until the final project, which involves a group collaborative project, and the prof provided absolutely no guidance whatsoever about what the project was supposed to be. we were supposed to develop it as a group, apparently. i wish she could have just acted like a professor and given us an assignment with meaningful parameters so we would actually know what we were supposed to do, instead of tossing meaningless ideas back and forth and never landing anywhere.

Strengths-- Professor Ramalingam is an amazing professor, and I loved taking this course with her. She is very reflexive to student need, and has an in-depth knowledge of current issues in museums. Assigned interesting and varying readings which meant that we were able to engage very interdisciplinary approaches to issues of display, knowledge production, and object repatriation. 
Weaknesses- the reading load was slightly higher than was helpful, and often meant we could not discuss all of them in class.

The course had really great readings and Prof. Ramalingham facilitated class discussion perfectly, knowing when to step back and when to push for more. Prof. Ramalingham was also very available to talk further and help push me to think harder on course topics. The only thing Id call a weakness is that it would be better to shorten the amount of readings because throughout the weeks we were consistently not fully talking about at least one of the weeks reading.

I liked the style of the course in which each class meeting per week was split up with a discussion of readings on the first class meeting and then a more interactive session such as museum site visits on the second class meeting. I think it would be cool in the future to include museums outside of Yale for students to visit. Additionally, while the final project had a collaborative aspect, I wish that rather than individual student projects being compiled together that students actually work together to make one big project ie curating a new exhibit together rather than a collection of reimagined exhibits to make it feel more collaborative. I would have appreciated being able to know what my grades were on assignments throughout the course, so I knew how I was doing in the course.

Strengths - trips to museums were amazing!!!!!!!!! and in class we had structured group work that was very helpful in my overall learning
Weaknesses - could really use a list of guiding questions for readings because often they are quite long and we don't really address all that's in them, the final project was a real struggle because it was difficult to have 8 people writing together (some of my stuff was literally just deleted) and some ideas were just disregarded when choosing the final project structure

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: interesting readings and course discussions. very easy short assignments, about 100 pages of readings each week (even though they are long and dense they are mostly interesting). course discussions skew hyper-liberal though, so be prepared to self-censor.
Yes, it is a good class if you want to learn more about the history of museums, and how perhaps to confront these histories.
Absolutely! Please take this course if you are interested in knowledge production, affect theory, feminist science studies, or have ever walked through a museum and felt something was off.
Id definitely recommend this course to anyone whos interested in museums or wanting to working in one. Even if you arent, I think this class was overall really interesting.
Yes! I highly recommend it to anyone who has any interest in museums and especially to students who like having a more interactive learning experience.
